awd_titl_txt: Collaborative:Elements:Cyberinfrastructure for Pedestrian Dynamics-Based Analysis of Infection Propagation Through Air Travel
awd_abstract_narration:
When people congregate - for example, at entertainment events, in crowds, and airplanes - they come into close contact with each other and can spread infectious diseases. The Disney World measles outbreak in 2016 is a prominent example. Air travel, in particular, is a leading factor in the spread of infections, and there have been several outbreaks of serious diseases that spread during air travel, such as SARS, H1N1 influenza, and tuberculosis. Public health policies and procedures for crowd management, boarding airplanes, etc. can help in mitigating the spread of disease, if these policies are science-based. The spread of directly transmitted diseases is governed by the movement patterns of people because the movement can bring an infected person close to others. The science of "pedestrian dynamics" provides mathematical models that can accurately simulate the movement of individuals in a crowd. These models allow scientists to understand how different policies, such as boarding procedures on planes, can prevent, or make worse, the transmission of infections. This project seeks to develop a novel software that will provide a variety of pedestrian dynamics models, infection spread models, as well as data so that scientists can analyze the effect of different mechanisms on the spread of directly transmitted diseases in crowded areas. The initial focus of this project is on air travel. However, the software can be extended to a broader scope of applications in movement analysis and epidemiology, such as in theme parks and sports venues. The project team is working closely with decision makers in airports, public health agencies, and the airline industry. This collaboration will lead to practical applications of this science that will improve public health. This project and the software will educate a wide range of scientists as well as students, in particular, students from under-represented groups, as well as professionals working in the public health fields.

This project seeks to develop a novel software that will provide a variety of pedestrian dynamics models, infection spread models, as well as data so that scientists can analyze the effect of different mechanisms on the spread of directly transmitted diseases in crowded areas. The initial focus of this project is on air travel. However, the software can be extended to a broader scope of applications in movement analysis and epidemiology, such as in theme parks and sports venues. Development of the proposed software will involve several innovations. It will include a novel phylogeography model that links fine-scale human movement data with virus genetic information to more accurately model geographic diffusion of viruses. New models for pedestrian movement will enable modeling of complex human movement patterns. A recommendation system for the choice of pedestrian dynamics models and a domain specific language for the input of policies and human behaviors will enhance usability by researchers in diverse fields. Community building initiatives will catalyze inter-disciplinary research to ensures the long-term sustainability of the project through a critical mass of contributors and users.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The project's primary goal was to develop innovative software to simulate human movement and understand how movement patterns influence the transmission of infectious diseases on both local and global scales, with a particular focus on the spread of infections during air travel. The project resulted in a cyberinfrastructure (CI) designed to enable fundamental scientific advances in decision-making related to epidemic spread. This CI incorporated several key innovations, including (1) new models for pedestrian movement to represent complex human movement patterns accurately, (2) a domain-specific language (DSL) for inputting policies and human behaviors, (3) a recommendation system for selecting appropriate pedestrian dynamics models, (4) community-building initiatives including two workshops aimed at fostering interdisciplinary research and ensuring the long-term sustainability of the CI.

Significant outcomes of the project are as follows: We made the production version of the VIPRA pedestrian dynamics simulation software, DSL, and recommender system available to the public. We implemented several human behaviors into the pedestrian dynamics code using the DSL. The DSL is our grammar for human behavior, which ANTLR uses to generate a parser in C++. The parser is compiled to create a Behavior Builder object that is linked with the basic pedestrian dynamics code. We used this framework to generate code corresponding to different human behaviors. We also developed a recommender system and deployed it to a public server. The VIPRA recommender system (VRS) is designed to assist users in selecting parameters and codes for pedestrian dynamics and infection spread analysis. We conducted a system usability study for the recommender system.

We adapted our models to study strategies for reducing COVID-19 spread, focusing on its immediate impact. By combining a dose-response model parameterized to superspreading events with pedestrian dynamics, we analyzed COVID-19 transmission during air travel. Using data from three flights—London to Hanoi (201 passengers, 13 secondary infections), Singapore to Hangzhou (321 passengers, 12-14 secondary infections), and a private jet in Japan (9 passengers, no secondary infections)—we demonstrated that including passenger movement better explains infection patterns than conventional models. Our findings showed that FFP2/N95 masks could reduce infections by 95-100%, while cloth masks would achieve only a 50-75% reduction. Additionally, airlines' back-to-front boarding process, introduced during the pandemic, doubles exposure compared to random boarding and increases exposure by 50% relative to pre-COVID zoned boarding. Although keeping middle seats empty reduces exposure significantly, the relative risks of boarding methods remain similar. The increased exposure stems from passenger proximity while moving in the aisle or seated.

Concerning computational performance, we found that low discrepancy sequence-based parameter sweeps effectively cover the parameter space in multiscale models involving pedestrian dynamics and infectious disease spread. In addition, our results show that pseudo-random and hybrid parameter sweeps have inherently low load imbalances compared with a low-discrepancy parameter sweep. However, they converge slower to the solution. Consequently, a low discrepancy-parameter sweep with dynamic load balancing is generally preferable to these alternatives.

The cyberinfrastructure, consisting of both software and data, developed through this project enabled these models and computational analyses.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2025
Modified by: Sirish Namilae
